Z.ai debuts open source GLM-4.6V, a native tool-calling vision model for multimodal reasoning

Zhipu AI launched GLM-4.6V, a new open-source vision-language model (VLM) series designed for enhanced multimodal reasoning and efficiency. The series includes tw…

Telegram AI Digest
#ai #huggingface #llm

external.description: Zhipu AI launched GLM-4.6V, a new open-source vision-language model (VLM) series designed for enhanced multimodal reasoning and efficiency. The series includes two models: a 106B parameter model and a smaller 9B parameter model.  A key innovation is the integration of native function calling, enabling direct tool use with visual inputs.  GLM-4.6V boasts a 128,000 token context window and excels on various benchmarks, competing with both closed and open-source VLMs. The models are available via API, web interface, and Hugging Face, licensed under MIT for flexible usage. GLM-4.6V employs a vision transformer and LLM decoder architecture, supporting diverse image and video inputs.  The model can perform tasks like report generation and visual web searches via multimodal function calling. GLM-4.6V shows strong performance on multiple benchmarks, surpassing similar sized existing models.  The model also supports frontend automation, replicating UIs and enabling long-context workflows.  Zhipu AI offers competitive pricing for the GLM-4.6V series, especially for its large model.
external.title: Z.ai debuts open source GLM-4.6V, a native tool-calling vision model for multimodal reasoning

value.text: Some closing thoughts for my students this semester on LLMs and learning #rstats datavizf25.classes.andrewheiss.com/news/2025-12...

images.alt:
Will you incorporate LLMs and AI prompting into the course in the future?
No.

Why won’t you incorporate LLMs and AI prompting into the course?
These tools are useful for coding (see this for my personal take on this).

However, they’re only useful if you know what you’re doing first. If you skip the learning-the-process-of-writing-code step and just copy/paste output from ChatGPT, you will not learn. You cannot learn. You cannot improve. You will not understand the code.

In that post, it warns that you cannot use it as a beginner:

…to use Databot effectively and safely, you still need the skills of a data scientist: background and domain knowledge, data analysis expertise, and coding ability.

There is no LLM-based shortcut to those skills. You cannot LLM your way into domain knowledge, data analysis expertise, or coding ability.

The only way to gain domain knowledge, data analysis expertise, and coding ability is to struggle. To get errors. To google those errors. To look over the documentation. To copy/paste your own code and adapt it for different purposes. To explore messy datasets. To struggle to clean those datasets. To spend an hour looking for a missing comma.

This isn’t a form of programming hazing, like “I had to walk to school uphill both ways in the snow and now you must too.” It’s the actual process of learning and growing and developing and improving. You’ve gotta struggle.

This Tumblr post puts it well (it’s about art specifically, but it applies to coding and data analysis too):

Contrary to popular belief the biggest beginner’s roadblock to art isn’t even technical skill it’s frustration tolerance, especially in the age of social media. It hurts and the frustration is endless but you must build the frustration tolerance equivalent to a roach’s capacity to survive a nuclear explosion. That’s how you build on the technical skill. Throw that “won’t even start because I’m afraid it won’t be perfect” shit out the window. Just do it. Just start. Good luck. (The original post has disappeared, but here’s a reblog.)

It’s hard, but struggling is the only way to learn anything.

You might not enjoy code as much as Williams does (or I do), but there’s still value in maintaining codings skills as you improve and learn more. You don’t want your skills to atrophy.

As I discuss here, when I do use LLMs for coding-related tasks, I purposely throw as much friction into the process as possible:

To avoid falling into over-reliance on LLM-assisted code help, I add as much friction into my workflow as possible. I only use GitHub Copilot and Claude in the browser, not through the chat sidebar in Positron or Visual Studio Code. I treat the code it generates like random answers from StackOverflow or blog posts and generally rewrite it completely. I disable the inline LLM-based auto complete in text editors. For routine tasks like generating {roxygen2} documentation scaffolding for functions, I use the {chores} package, which requires a bunch of pointing and clicking to use.

Even though I use Positron, I purposely do not use either Positron Assistant or Databot. I have them disabled.

So in the end, for pedagogical reasons, I don’t foresee me incorporating LLMs into this class. I’m pedagogically opposed to it. I’m facing all sorts of external pressure to do it, but I’m resisting.

You’ve got to learn first.

record.text:
Haymarket in Melbourne is a great example of intersection management that crams as many cursed cars through as possible, while also slowing trams down.

2011 changes saw general traffic lanes added and lights installed. Previously, trams had priority; now, they wait for lights.

images.alt:
Aerial image via Nearmap of the Haymarket roundabout from 2010. 
Image shows a large, multi-lane roundabout with a complex tram junction in the middle.

Image of the Haymarket roundabout in Melbourne from 2025 via Nearmap. 
Compared to the preceding image, there has been an additional lane squeezed in to the roundabout at several sections, and traffic lights have been added.

Aerial image via Nearmap of the Haymarket roundabout from 2010. 
Image shows a large, multi-lane roundabout with a complex tram junction in the middle.

Image of the Haymarket roundabout in Melbourne from 2025 via Nearmap.

record.text: whereas irl hoarding, my room is filled with random garbage with nowhere to put it. random electrical components that might potentially serve some utility in a future project, but they have no home, and i just have like 20 cheap radial potentiometers from broken analogue sticks in a stupid drawer.

I'm definitely worse than the median in terms of "hoarding", I've probably played ~5% of my owned titles, but i wouldn't necessarily even call that hoarding, because the behavior isn't quite the same. like there's basically zero detrimental effects from having an extra title in your library.

i buy for several different reasons:
- sincerely plan on playing but distracted by other titles
- vague future plans to play
- want to play, see it on sale for good price (impulse buy)
- support the dev in the abstract but don't really wanna play the game
- bundled with a title i really want

Worldwide, more than 60 percent of ski slopes utilize artificial snow.   Ski areas use around 50 to 400 million gallons of water to make snow.  Water is often pumped from surrounding water bodies, which can bring lakes and streams to dangerously low water levels and threaten fish and wildlife.

value.text: A great deal of AI hype is coming from con artists who understand exactly how much easier it’s going to be to use the same cons over and over once they achieve their dream of a world in which nobody understands how anything 1) works or 2) has ever worked.

Shallow "Just summarize this for me" attitudes toward understanding how anything works guarantees that we will fall prey to endless repackaging of old, tired, failed ideas as innovations. When you don't know anything, everything sounds brand new.

images.alt:
"The sky is ablaze with color, a radiant sunset spilling golden-orange light across a canvas of dramatic clouds. The sun itself is hidden, but its presence is unmistakable—its rays pierce through the cloud cover like divine brushstrokes, casting beams of light that fan outward in luminous arcs. The clouds are thick and textured, some dark and brooding, others glowing at the edges as if lit from within.

Below this celestial drama, the silhouettes of trees and a rooftop anchor the scene. The trees stand like quiet witnesses, their branches etched in black against the fiery sky. The rooftop is simple, angular, and shadowed—an earthly counterpoint to the sky’s grandeur.

The colors are intense and layered: deep amber, molten gold, hints of crimson and violet where the light meets the cloud’s edge. The atmosphere feels charged, almost mythic—as if the day is being folded into night with ceremony and fire." - Microsoft Copilot
